div.p: piriviṭai vēṟuppaṭṭāḷaik kaṇṭu tōḻi vaṟpuṟuppāṭkuk kiḻatti uraittatu.
Spoken by HER to the one who encouraged [her], [namely] the confidante at the sight of her who had changed in the time of separation.

lg.l: Our [man], (Cām.,T.V.G.: HE also is the subject of the abs. cūṭi ) This poem is an especially fine example of 5 lines of unmarked syntax. It can be construed in several ways, and none of them is much more satisfactory than the other as far as content is concerned. Here is the traditional interpretation. o red-jewel[led one] To take cēyiḻai with Cām. as a vocative means reading it as a totally unmarked metonymy. There are few examples of this kind. So it might also be possible to take it as an attribute for HIM, "who has a red decoration" (which makes even better sense in the close parallel of KT 348.6 with māṇiḻai which might be "who has glory for his decoration"). But on the other hand iḻai is normally used for the decoration of women (except for a chariot in KT 345.1), so it seems safer to stick to a vocative. , has he gone
to the forest, where on Talai on kuṉṟu talai has been taken as a locative suffix, though it might have been chosen intentionally here: the heads of the hills. the hills,

worn for [their] heads So to me the picture seems to be that the heads of the hills have for their full and curly hair the fronds of the Palmyra, adorned with Neem flowers. with curly full mane to shine Strange here the accumulation of light: poliya ... vāṉpū ... veṇṭōṭṭu ... paiṅkāl ... veṇmaṇal (contrasting moreover with cēyiḻai of the last line). Is the focus a peculiar illumination, perhaps at the moment of sunset? Palm leaves at least are usually not white.,
the dense sky(light) flower of the Neem tree by the path united
with the white mass of crests of the rounded Palmyra
with sharp edges [and] fresh stems Are paiṅkāṟ karukkiṉ attributes of the tree or of the leaves? , thriving

in the white sands Strange is also the amalgamation of regions. There is kāṉam in line 5 combined with kuṉṟu . This might be read as a climax of distance and the direction of HER look: she in the village, then the forest, behind it the hills. But what of veṇ maṇal , a typical attribute of the seaside region? ?
Has he gone, o red-jewel[led one], our [man],
to the forest united with hills Cām.'s gloss ignores the talai of this line. ,

having worn, for [his] curly full tuft of hair on the head to shine Is the connection of the Neem with the Pāṇṭiyas really enough to justify the conjecture of His wearing a flower garland and going to war for them? Certainly men too are occasionally said to wear flowers (when mounting the Palmyra horse in KT 17 or the shepherd wearing jasmine buds in KT 122), but what is the point here? A.D. thinks that the confidante reassures HER by reminding her that he has left the village well protected – the white flowers of the Neem or Margosa having protecting quality. But why the addition as to the Palmyra? T.V.G. explains that the Neem flowers are too small to have hold by themselves, and that the Palmyra-leaves are used to stabilise them. ,
the sky(light) flowers of the Neem by the path
together with white masses of crests of the rounded Palmyra

with sharp edges [and] fresh stems, thriving in the white sands? Actually the Palmyras of line 1 and 2 can either be part of the head dress, or they can be understood as attributes o attam , the road he travels.
